threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format and ideally smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking.
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the Catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads).

Do not want:
• Go to /wsr/ or /r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

Want to learn more?
• The /p/ Wiki

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Halloween Edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY -https://textbin.net/2u146abxla
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://web.archive.org/web/20200926115310/https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

>NO ONE CARES WHAT AN EXPERT YOU THINK YOU ARE. IF YOU’RE ASKING BASIC-AS-SHIT QUESTIONS, YOU CAN’T BE ALL THAT GREAT. SEE ABOVE

Previous thread >>4085831

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Anything that works, shoots at least 1080p and preferably has interchangeable lenses. Any recommendation beyond that will cause arguments so read the fucking sticky if that isn't satisfactory.
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Can someone tell me if my video is any good?
Yes, but be prepared to receive harsh criticism. If you're going to waste 5 minutes of our time with a shitty out-of-focus montage of nothing then we'll tell you that it's crap

>>4099579
It actually depends on the viewing device. Small resolution jpegs on high res phone screens, for example, will look worse than png of the same resolution. TV screens are guilty of this as well. They see low res jpeg and loves to throw scaling algorithms over it. With png they must at least obey baked in colour space. This goes for 8bit png, 24bit tends to be overkill in most cases, but can be used as means of getting rid of banding.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101542
Not sure what you're working for budget wise, but I'll try to address what I can.

First off, understand that the Canon kit lens is just not a very good lens optically. I will get you by, but under perform in pretty much every regard.

As for 50mm on your kit vs 50mm on the 1.8 yes they are the same focal length. But the 50mm prime lens is such a vast improvement in image quality. It's easily worth it to grab. You can use it in much lower light then your kit lens too. When it comes to prime lenses you have to plan around them, and get used to them, there's no getting away from that.

I probably wouldn't bother with the 17-50mm lens, though it is nice that it's f2.8 through out the entirety of it's focal length. I think it does some macro too. Not my style, but you could do more with this lens over the kit lens.

the 18-135 really is redundant as it covers all the same focal lengths of the other lenses you are looking at. I would instead suggest the 55-250mm IS STM lens. Very sharp lens, low price, fast and silent focusing too.

>>4101457
>Seeing the world through the lens instead of a faggy LCD
Fucking based.

>>4101472
>who says they do? good straw man friend
He's not saying other people are claiming this and then attacking it. He's merely pointing it out as an EVF problem. Fucking hell we can't schools properly teach logic and the fallacies?

>i get more reliable AF from modern mirrorless than i ever did with a dslr, eye auto focus is amazing, i have to "trust" a DSLR far more
If you know how to use DSLR AF there's not much difference in capture rate. Admittedly though this takes practice while mirrorless AI AF pretty much works out of the box for anyone.

>except you have to deal with af fine tuning because the af sensor is offset from the imaging sensor
If you check and adjust your lenses when you first buy them you never have to deal with this. It's a non-issue for anyone who just takes 10m to check a new lens.

>worse ability to see in extreme dark,
This one is simply false. With a few exceptions, mirrorless EVFs go to shit in truly dark conditions. Try framing the Milky Way on mirrorless, or Orion nebula. Those are visible in an OVF with a fast lens. There are only a few mirrorless bodies which can gain up the EVF to make them visible.

Even at a low light level where an EVF is brighter, right before the EVF falls off a cliff and can't see shit, fps and lag go to shit and noise becomes visible. There's no way around this as the camera has to drop the shutter speed and push ISO to max.

>>The mirrorless fans are
>ad hom ad hom, but fairplay for my boomer take
How is it an ad hom to make an observation about the average age of the market? Eyesight acuity does decrease with age, therefore there are age related differences in preferences for things like OVF vs. EVF. You could ask him for statistical evidence, but he did not commit an ad hom.

>>4101439
kek... watch what happens. The first step will be moving away from the term mirrorless and then new "hybrid" features will be offered. All in the same form factor, which they could have already done. My composition rules are as follows: the rule of thirds in any way possible, baroque and sister diagnonals, rule of odds, rule of sixths in any way possible, filling the frame, center framing in any way possible, the simple viewing of the image, one point perspective, two point perspective, three point perspective, leading lines, geometric shapes, figure ground relationship, seperating shapes, symetrical balance, asymmetrical balance, group mass, rule of space, frame in a frame, corners, organizing like a paper, quadrant system, rhythm based on nature and patterns, bordering the image with space. Help me find other composition rules so that I can take a quick nice looking photo for the other 20%.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101416
Golden Ratio is too complicated as with the dynamic symmetry. I mainly use the rule of thirds, rule of sixths, center framing on my T2i. Fibonacci spiral doesn't allow much room for movement too for the subject. While all of my composition method are plentiful, they all can be simply framed in less than 15 seconds. Take group mass for example. Say there is a huge tree in a forest with the other trees appearing smaller, well you just simply zoom into that tree and you get a balanced image. The concepts I'm offering are based on designs and painting techniques before the 19th century.

yeah. there are three ways to go basically.

2, you obsess over made up subjective bullshit, ranging from "3d pop" to "magic CCD colors" to "leica look", etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101442
If you are buying a nice camera with the goal of making prints, you should be inclined to buy a nice lens on the basis of its specs, because you are not going to be able to tell if you take the output of each lens and scale them down to blog size.
Likewise if you are buying an expensive camera with the goal of low light photography you might want to look at the noise charts rather than okay-light SOOC jpeg snapshits scaled down to blog size.

But if you are not spending a lot of money and just want to take generic photos it's not such a big deal

editing is arguably the most important aspect of photography. no matter how interesting your subject, composition, and the overall context of your work is, it must have striking contrast, colors, and other things. In most cases, editing is where your personal style is most clearly defined. Do you go for low saturated earth tones and intentional underexposure? Do you go for pastel colors with high luminance? very saturated primary colors? low contrast b&w? cinematic color grading? What's your style and how do you achieve it

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Is conventional advice for beginner gear fundamentally wrong?
threads.com:
Is conventional beginner gear advice not just wrong but even one of the leading causes of GAS?

A lot of people are being led to believe that focal length is a lot more important than it really is. Which is somewhat natural, it's a lot more intuitive than something like f-numbers.

So usually you will start with the kit 18-55mm on APS-C. Then you add a similarly lacklustre tele zoom and a wide zoom. Or a superzoom. Or maybe several low quality primes, someone told you they were sharper. And now you've gone and spent quite a bit of money and have more choices than you know what to do with. And none of them are weather sealed, so that limits how much you can actually be out and shoot. And when you do you have tons of chromatic aberration, distortion, high ISO noise, cluttered ultra-wide scenes and hazy ultra-long ones. It's just not fun anymore. So you try to fill the void with even more gear that you don't know what to do with, if you haven't financially ruined yourself yet.

Why not instead get just one really stellar lens from the start and stick with it? Maybe a constant f2.8 standard zoom, or a fast prime somewhere in that range. You can always get more later when you have the skill set to make use of them, but a lot of the great masters went their whole career with just one or two lenses, or lenses no more extreme than what is found in the said standard zoom, and it didn't hold back any of them.

What do you guys think, is it time to fundamentally reconsider what we tell beginners about what gear to get? What advice would you have wanted to hear before getting your first serious camera?

last_replies.com:
>>4100518

I actually use one of those cell phone repair kits that comes with a screwdriver and like 100 bits.

Get a set of lens spanners, very small set of slip jaw pliers like Channel locks but very tiny. You'll want some assorted lubricants that are camera specific, I use Japan Hobby Tool. Believe it or not, Cera Vie blue bottle works good too. It's a hand moisturizer. You'll also want a set of lens filter straighteners, looks like a vice.

You'll want some small metal and plastic brushes. A tooth brush. Retractable magnet wand.

Maybe this week I'll post my setup.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: I bought a Canon R10 - Did I make a mistake?
threads.com:
So 5-6 years ago I purchased a Canon 6D with a "nifty fifty" as well as a 35mm Sigma Art f/1.4 lens. It cost me about $2000, which was a lot of money for me at the time (especially since I'm only a hobby photographer).

Anyway, I wanted to upgrade to a mirrorless camera due to its better autofocusing system etc, so after a lot of reading (I was mostly researching full frame cameras), I ended up ordering an APS-C camera (the Canon R10).

My thinking was, due to the 1.6x crop factor, my 50mm would become an 80mm lens and my 35mm Sigma would become 56mm. And I wanted a lens in this region for portrait photography.

But now I hear that just attaching one of these full frame lenses via an EF to RF mount, could actually make the IQ worse.

Did I make a mistake buying a cropped sensor camera? Especially since I mostly do portrait photography nowadays? Should I have just sold everything I had and started fresh with a full-frame Sony or Nikon?

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Mt. Erebus (Antarctica), 1955. Just look at this shit. If someone were to take a picture like this on a digital camera it would be called overprocessed dogshit but here it is. I don't know what my point is but every once in a while I come across a great old analog pic and I just think: why can't digital look like that? Well, maybe it can, we're just afraid to make it happen.
For example many analog snaps are super duper warm. On digi cams we put "auto white balance" but that's bullshit, back in the days a roll of film had just 1 white balance whether it was sunny or cloudy or you were inside a fluorescent lit office. So what if you'd just fix your white balance on "overcast" and stop giving a shit that your pixels aren't perfectly averaged to xxxx kelvin? Just saying.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101063
>Well, maybe it can, we're just afraid to make it happen.
sometimes this is definitely the case. part of the film look is very high contrast, or lack of detail, et cetera. however, this isn't a constant. there are plenty of film photos that are characterized by their low contrast instead, and plenty that posess great levels of detail. yet they're still recognizable as film photos. this is why film is so difficult to emulate. you can apply a fixed effect to an image but that just isn't good enough.
>For example many analog snaps are super duper warm. On digi cams we put "auto white balance" but that's bullshit, back in the days a roll of film had just 1 white balance whether it was sunny or cloudy or you were inside a fluorescent lit office. So what if you'd just fix your white balance on "overcast" and stop giving a shit that your pixels aren't perfectly averaged to xxxx kelvin?
I've tried this. since most films were daylight balanced, I've tried just fixing the white balance to daylight and using that. but the strange thing is, film seems to behave differently than digital with white balance. a shot taken in a given set of conditions on film will end up looking far more color accurate than a digital shot taken in the same circumstances with the white balance set to daylight. the digital shot will very rapidly end up looking extremely inaccurate: either much too warm or much too cool. I don't know why this is.
I encourage you to try this yourself. you'll see the strange difference. it even holds for indoor shots. film photos will look warm, yes, but nowhere near the clownishly yellow results you'll get from shooting daylight white balance indoors under artificial light with digital.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4101063
it's an unedited amateur snapshot. you can do this on digital. you just don't want to because you have the option not to.

digital just brought darkroom fuckery and formerly expensive techniques to the masses. you must understand that a lot of professional film shooters had interchangeable backs with different film stocks, identical cameras with different film stocks - not just for white balance and color cast, but also for ISO sensitivtity. push this roll two stops, pull that roll two stops. now you can do this on a per image basis...

but you can still just leave the ISO at 400 all day, leave the white balance on a fixed setting, and shoot jpegs if you want to.

pros used to take their developed film and enlarge them optically. during this process they would edit the white balance and color balance with filters between the negative/slide and the larger film, and burn and dodge the enlargement to darken highlights and bring out shadows. just like sing LIGHTroom. but it was called the darkroom. digital did nothing more than make this an affordable process that didn't involve sensitive film stocks, expensive, toxic chemistry, pricey enlargers, and a whole room dedicated to it....

but you can always go old school and just take your walmart 1 hour photo equivalents (SOOC jpegs) and enjoy them as is.

you might as well say "zooms bad because you only need one focal length" meanwhile pros used to have a camera with each prime hanging from their neck

Yes it's another gear thread, sorry guys. But you'll tell it to me like it is with no hype or shilling.

So I'm looking into buying into a full frame mirrorless system. I shoot seriously, but not professionally (I don't depend on it for my main income). I'm looking at used cameras in the 'enthusiast / low end professional' spectrum, so basically SontyA7(R/S)ii/iii, Nikon Z6i/ii, Canon EOS R. I'm hoping to get a used camera, and one or two decent primes for around 2000 USD.

I shoot mainly event photography at 'alternative events', very frequently wth poor or moody lighting, so low light performance and noise quality is important to me. I am a huge raw processing / color calibration geek, so I basically don't care at all about how images look SOOC.

Yes, I know that it's the photographer and not the gear and all that, but also I'm looking at spending quite a bit of money and buying into an ecosystem here so I'd like to consider my options carefully.

So are there any clear winners here, or clear losers to avoid?

I am currently the frustrated owner of a Nikon D3300 with a kit lens (18-55mm), a prime 50mm 1.8, and a 55-200mm DX.

I would like to buy a better camera, and I am considering either the D7500 or the D800. Both are approx. the same price (~€700) where I live.

Which one should I choose?

I mostly do portraits but I also like doing landscape and boudoir photography from time to time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4099907
It's not just the autofocus feature, it's a century of advancement in optics and going from lenses that only had to resolve well enough for grainy, flawed, chemically reproduced images that would be treated as something around 16mp to lenses that need to resolve enough detail with much tamer aberrations to justify a 36mp sensor. Basically if you're going to use dated and super cheap chink glass you don't need a D800, you are spending half a grand extra on extra camera you are barely using. The sensor is just resolving the blurry image from the lens better so you can really see every little aberration and optical fuckup.

A single modern nikkor prime is going to make the D800 worth your money otherwise for dated glass go ahead and save your money, use dated gear. Gearfaggotry will not make the photographer, and can even make a lazy photographer, but it is important if you want to avoid wasting enough money to buy a running car when doing so will not make you a better photographer.

By the time you can, both will be cheaper because even higher quality shit will have been released. the sony A7RVI will come with something like an 80mp sensor and kits of zeiss glass that still out-resolve it and older sub-50mp DSLRs and their lenses will be experiencing film SLR levels of depreciation.

>>4100528
>While this is a legit complain compared to modern bodies, the truth is that if you cant focus with it you are doing it wrong. Sure, more is always better but we reached good enough levels long long ago
It is clear that you don't shoot in motion. My point of view is different. For me, image resolution has been good enough for a long time. While I can do most of the camera work as manually as necessary, that's a tradeoff of effort, time and image control for missed and often technically inferior shots. We have near-perfect automatic metering methods for autofocus and exposure, but the cameras' automatic modes often don't work the way the user wants them to, even unreliably in certain situations, then in others better than the userr would achieve. Still, even the most advanced cameras have room for improvement in terms of configuration and control options, adjustability in general, and user interface. Photographers/cinematographers would have been replaced by robots long ago if automodes were enough, but the story against that is that the more professional the images become, the more work has to replace automodes, especially because automodes are still not reliable enough, not enough in control enough.

Thanks anon. I'd say posting here probably won't get you a whole lot of fame. I'd say that having quality work and a quality website full of useful information is a good start. >>4097604
I use the tetenal 3-bath kits. Let's see if all my slides looks like trash in 20 years! Slides actually don't hold up all that well anyway, I'm pretty amazed when clients send me film from the 80s and 90s and it's terribly color shifted. The only slide that seems to hold up is Kodachrome.

Jobos are easy to use and the results are great so long as you do a prewash step with sheets. You can expect to get the cost down to about $1 per sheet for color with consistent results. That price is of course not including the system itself which may run you about $2000 if you find a reasonable used machine and expert drum.

>>4099415
Thank you for helping put me at ease
>>4099416
I don't want to go wide I just want to be a few inches away from my models

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: >>4099188

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4099499
I mean if you want to be a few inches away from your model and still capture a large portion of them then you're gonna have to go somewhat wide. Unless you mean minimum focus distance, in which case on the 16-55 for example is 30cm, on primes like the 18/1.4 and 23/1.4 about 20cm, the 30/2.8 macro can do 10cm. Remember those figures are from the sensor plane, so the 30/2.8 for example has a minimum working distance of about 1.2cm (from the surface of the lens).

The easiest way really is just taking whatever you shoot on FF and dividing that by 1.52. 50mm FF=33mm Fuji, 35mm FF=23mm Fuji, 24mm FF=16mm Fuji. You'll get the same field of view that way. Like >>4099416 and >>4099235 said, you won't run into problems unless you go really really wide, where you'll still find lenses (the 8-16/2.8 for example) but they're basically as expensive as their FF counterparts.

last_replies.com:
Ken Rockwell gets a lot of stick and he is laughing all the way to the bank. Consider that he may even be rabble-rousing on purpose. Do what works for you, not what you think the world wants.
There are far too many people in the world who attempt to pander to everyone to make them all feel better. Art (and photography certainly falls in the same category), is a sensitive subject, but opinions are just opinions, we all have them. It doesn’t make me right and you wrong.
We have different beliefs and different ideas of what we like and what we want. Often purchasers look to people to validate the decisions that they have made in buying the right camera, or the right lens. What they really wanted was to know themselves what they should do.
I’m sure Ken doesn’t mind being a source of information that encourages people to click on his affiliate links, but I’m sure if it came down to it he would probably say that if you are asking me whether you should buy a new camera or lens, the answer is no.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Film is the Real Deal

Ken is a big fan of photographic film, and film photography is for people who know their sh*t. In this sense he scores some kudos points.
When I started off shooting film, I took Ken’s advice and went with slide film and the WYSIWYG benefit. The initial results were pretty bad, but they did teach me a lot about photography, and the use of light, exposure latitude, apertures and shutter speeds, and how to deal with high dynamic range scenes.
I think I jumped in at the deep end. Truthfully, shooting negative film will give you better results to start with, but you need to find a good lab to scan your negs. When you get the hang of it, and you can nail your exposures, you can move over to slide film.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Ken Rockwell calls film the “real RAW” format. I like this attitude in the sense that a well exposed film photograph is a testament to good photographic technique. By contrast modern digital cameras will produce better results from the off, but they do take something away from the photographer’s skill. I still think that if you know what you are doing, you can get nicer looking results with a film camera than you can with a digital one.
I’m not suggesting if Ansel Adams was alive today, that he would still be using a view camera instead of shooting medium format in RAW and getting busy in Photoshop.
He was such an advocate of post processing techniques that I’m sure he would have loved the advances modern digital photography has brought to the table.
But there is no substitute for knowing and mastering the basics of photography, and if you shoot film a lot, you’ve got to know what you’re doing because digital is a lot more forgiving, and the camera does a lot of the work for you.
There isn’t much fancy electronics in a film camera. The Fuji GF670 and GF670W and the Voigtlander bessa III and III W (basically rebadged Fuji GF670 with a different finish) is a MF film camera that you can buy new today, but it is still a pretty basic user experience compared to a basic digital camera. If you can shoot a film camera well, you know what you’re doing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4098805
I think negative film actually has more dynamic range anyways, and reversing a drum scan in LR is not rocket science, or inferior to just using a drum scan (or any backlit scan) of slide film.

>>4098806
Film just looks better because clipping in either direction is smooth, halation is reminiscent of "eye burn", and film grain has a natural sandy appearance that is calming like most natural things. The overall experience is more serene and less exciting. You look at film, you examine digital. I don't think digital can simulate it 100%, but film is still best reserved for special occasions. Digital is a lot more fun and digital cameras make excellent light meters and can be useful for getting composition right in extreme low light but film is unreliable, expensive, and does not last forever. Developed originals degrade and drum scanning can already out-resolve film. .dng files can be backed up 1:1 indefinitely.

No, it's definitely a big meme in and of itself. there's nothing wrong with it, but it had a huge surge in popularity and any young, suburban man who had a shred of interest in art photography over the past, what, eight years has probably had a new topography phase. It's a big thing on Instagram, too, last I saw; any dude with a camera can take a photo of whatever building corner, wash out the colours, say "I am elevating le banol" and they'll get likes. I don't want to hate, but it does have a newbie connotation to me since it was what I did for a few years when I was a baby artfag taking pictures of building corners and signposts with my film camera pretending like I had an idea of what I was actually doing and not just copying other dudes I saw on Instagram.

Anyway, long ramble, but new topo is definitely a meme. Not a bad meme, but still a meme.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4092196
>Not a bad meme, but still a meme.
Any defined genre is a meme. In the case of New Topographics it was defined by William Jenkins, the curator of the original exhibition, in 1975.

Prior to that none of the photographers knew they were shooting New Topographics. Since then anyone who works with vaguely similar subjects is tarred and feathered with the same brush and is judged on how closely they managed to pastiche the originals.

Penumbral eclipse begins at 08:02 UTC on November 8 (3:02 a.m. EST).
Partial eclipse begins at 09:09 UTC on November 8 (4:09 a.m. EST).
Totality begins (moon engulfed in Earth’s shadow) begins at 10:16 UTC on November 8 (5:16 a.m. EST).
Totality ends at 11:41 UTC on November 8 (6:41 a.m. EST).

1xroll of portra 400=$26
develop said roll of portra=$10
=$36 for 36 photos or $1 per click.

My DSLR costs $1500 and can take 150,000 clicks.

With these type or price comparisons shooting film just can not be justified.

The material cost are only a fraction of the retail price. A roll of film has ballpark 0.25g silver in it, for this the manufacturer has to buy 0.4g silver nitrate which costs them south of $1/g

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4092977
>No, you hipster, photography has never been a poor mans hobby, be it digital or film.
If you used drug-store film and took your stuff to Costco to get it developed and printed, film photography was cheap. If you shot B&W and developed it yourself, film was cheap.
If you were OK with what came from a machine print, there was a cheap 30" x 20" print you could get for maybe $14. It was a stretch to print 35mm at that size, but I had a few shots on slow film and a good lens where it looked impressive.
What was not cheap was slide film and things like Cibachrome prints, and of course Polaroid was never cheap. Gotta hand it to Cibachrome, though, I have prints from the early 1990s which still look as good as new.
